title: Thursday, 3rd November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

...... uh, well, hello I guess.

BE

How on earth do we go about tackling this session?

BE

I guess, in a break from tradition, we can start with something relevant to markets.

11:04 am
BE

Here's the tick chart for JP Morgan's UK domestic basket (white) vs its UK exporter basket (yellow), normalised at 100 at 8am.

BE

BE

What happened just after 10am, of course, is the discovery that the rule of law's kind-of a fundamental principle on this wet wee rock we find ourselves.

11:06 am
BE

You can pick through the full judgement here ...

BE

https://www.judici...he-european-union/

BE

From a skim read my favourite bit so far is paragraph 94 ...

11:06 am
BE

Where the court notes that the government's position is invalid from the get-go, before even hearing the claimants' arguments.

BE

BE

So anyway, the PM can't send an Article 50 notification without an act of Parliament

11:07 am
BE

Soft Brexit looks more of a possibility than it was yesterday.

BE

Sterling up, stocks all over the place depending on their earnings denomination as much as anything else .........

BE

............. and at this point, the ROTR can ruminate, speculate, hypothecate and vociferate about what happens next.

11:09 am
BE

Because the ROTL doesn't have a clue.

undefined
BE

Movers, then.

11:11 am

That's soft Brexit.

That's soft Brexit.

11:12 am
BE

I could do this all show. And actually I might.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 261.80, up 8.9 (+3.52%), High: 262.70, Low: 252.20, Volume: 10.72m
BE

That's soft Brexit.

11:12 am
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 477.54, up 12.84 (+2.76%), High: 477.90, Low: 453.30, Volume: 2.58m
BE

That's soft Brexit.

BE

.... actually, I'll stop, because there are a few other things happening.

11:13 am
BE

Such as Dixphone.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 343.00, up 16.6 (+5.09%), High: 348.40, Low: 328.00, Volume: 2.47m
BE

Which, aside from soft Brexit, is Morgan Stanley's Geoff Ruddell closing his short.

11:14 am
BE

Valuation mostly.

BE

Dixons Carphone has derated significantly in recent months
and consensus is no longer predicting much earnings growth in
outer years. We believe, therefore, that the risk-reward trade
off has become much more balanced, so upgrade to Equal-
weight.

BE

I like Geoff's reports a lot. He's straightforward.

11:15 am
BE

We have been long-term bears... When we downgraded Dixons Carphone to
Underweight in January 2015 we did so because we believed that it's lofty PE
multiple (c17x forward earnings) did not reflect the longer-term structural
pressures on its mobile business and because we believed it would struggle to
deliver much earnings growth beyond FY 2016/17 (once its merger synergies had
been exploited).
...and been right, though partly for the wrong reasons. Although we did not
envisage Brexit being the catalyst, Dixons Carphone has now derated to what we
consider much more appropriate levels. Moreover consensus forecasts for outer
years have come back significantly, bringing them broadly into line with our own
expectations (which have changed little in the last couple of years),

BE

..... so .............

BE

Risk Reward now much more balanced. We still have structural concerns about
the longer-term outlook for Dixons Carphone's mobile business and it is hard to
rule out a sharp slowdown in UK consumer spending at some point in the next
couple of years. On the other hand, although the company has not indicated its
intentions in this regard, we are conscious that Carphone management has
historically created very significant value for its shareholders through M&A
activity and, with the merger with Dixons completed more than two years ago, we
would not be surprised if further such activity were to come back on to its
agenda in due course.
Upgrading to Equal-weight. Although we leave our long-standing 315p price
target unchanged today, this now represents just 3% downside. We believe it is
appropriate, therefore, to upgrade our rating to Equal-weight.

11:17 am
BE

Which is the first page, but it also goes on to really interesting stuff about what shape Carphone would be in if Dixons hasn't bought it.

BE

As in, handset makers increasingly using direct sales, customers increasingly going sim-free and-or media bundles.

BE

Network consolidation, the ever diminishing returns of smartphone upgrades, etc etc etc.

11:20 am
BE

MOST's argument is, "yeah, problem. But not something to worry about immediately, because the PE's already been crushed."

BE

These pressures do not so much represent downside risk to
earnings forecasts over the next year or two, as they do risk to the valuation multiple
applied to these earnings. Clearly, however, there was a much greater risk of derating
when the shares were trading on 17x earnings a couple of years ago, than there is now
that the shares are trading at c10x.

undefined
11:21 am
BE

Article 50 sellside beginning to drip through now ......

BE

Citi's Christian Shulz writes ..........

BE

While the government will appeal before the Supreme Court (SC), the decision is a political blow to Prime Minister Theresa May who had insisted that she could trigger the EU exit process alone. We do not expect parliament to reverse the referendum, but we cannot rule out delays and generally more involvement of MPs, who in their vast majority supported the ‘Remain’ side, in the Brexit process. A bigger role for parliament reduces the risk of “Hard Brexit” a little.

11:21 am
BE

We would not expect parliament to stop the invocation of Article 50 TEU if it does get to vote on it, even if more than two-thirds of MPs leaned towards ‘Remain’. Parliament overwhelmingly authorized the EU Referendum Act in 2015 (only the SNP rejected it) and former PM Cameron was clear before the referendum that a vote to leave the EU would lead to a swift invocation of Article 50. Still, a parliamentary vote would be a setback for the PM who had firmly argued that triggering EU exit would be her decision and it could resurface divisions within the Conservative Party, perhaps undermining the stability of government. MPs could feel empowered to demand the revelation of the government’s negotiating strategy, including whether it aims to continue Single Market access and Customs Union membership.

BE

The government said in its submissions to the Court that a parliamentary ratification vote on the negotiation outcome was “very likely”. However, MPs room for manoeuvre at that stage would be constrained by the alternative available, ie. whether rejection means continued EU membership or “hard Brexit” without any deal at all. A final ruling by the SC that parliament gets to vote on Article 50 would set a precedent and perhaps also lead to more parliamentary involvement and even votes during the negotiation process. The referendum gave MPs no direct guidance on which kind of Brexit voters want, so parliament would be free to reject the government’s negotiation aims and results.

BE

The government will appeal against the judgment in the SC, which observers expect to hear the case in December. The High Court took about two weeks between the three-day hearing in mid-October and the judgment today. We would expect the SC’s final judgment to arrive in January at the latest. That could allow enough time for Parliament to vote in time for the government to trigger Article 50 in line with the current timeline “by March 2017”, but we cannot rule out delays.

11:23 am
BE

And congratulations in particular to Tim Leckie of JP Morgan ......

BE

........ who's first out of the traps with a "what this means for my sector" note.

BE

In this case, reits.

11:24 am
BE

In our view this is not necessarily a clear positive for UK REITs, especially those with London office exposure, as it creates further uncertainty and muddies the already murky waters around the UK’s future position and issues such as access to the common market. The government could appeal the decision or the parliamentary vote process could be drawn out, lengthening the period of uncertainty that investors, landlords and tenants are currently facing

BE

(.... Not that Mr Leckie will be able to read those congratulations in the JPM office, of course.)

11:28 am
undefined
BE

Inmarsat, I think, was mentioned on the right.

BE

Q3 beats, revenue guidance repeated.

11:30 am
BE

The best news is that Global Xpress looks to be gaining traction.

BE

Maritime -- which is about half of group revenues, remember -- is still in a sinkhole

BE

(@Mouselet: GoCompare spinout, so ceteris paribus nothing)

11:32 am
BE

FX also rather helpful.

BE

Here's Goldman.

BE

ISAT has reported 3Q16 results +1%/+7% revenue/EBITDA (ex Ligado)
versus consensus (company). Overall we view the results as supportive
with long term guidance reiterated; strong EBITDA performance includes
benefits of weaker sterling vs. US$. Within the mix, maritime trends clearly
remain tough but we continue to see long term demand for VSAT with
evidence of good growth in the quarter and distribution deals as key to
future growth. Government also delivered a sharp acceleration in growth
which is welcome and a broader trend across 3Q ISAT results. Reiterate Buy.

11:32 am
BE

3Q16 – Maritime weak, government ahead – Maritime growth in the
quarter deteriorated to -4.9% (from 2Q16 -0.5%, 1Q16 -4.5%), although
ISAT cites that VSAT revenue growth remains strong (including 110 Fleet
Express installations) and the FleetBroadband base continued to see a fall
in the installed base in part due to a clean up on non-paying Sim’s and
smaller vessels. Government posted a strong performance at +9.8% (2Q16
+2.3%, 1Q16 +2.8%) while Aero was +10.1% (2Q16 +8.4%, 1Q16 +15.1%).
Ligado was also ahead at $35m. Outlook – Guidance for 2016E revenues of
$1,175m-$1,250m is unchanged but ISAT has now lowered capex guidance
for 2016E to $400m-500m (from $500m-600m previously) due to the
delayed I-5 F4 launch. All other guidance has been reiterated. Aviation -
IAG announced yesterday that it has signed a deal with Inmarsat to provide
in-flight connectivity. There are no further details in the release this
morning, but we expect this to be a focus on the call today.

BE

........... Hm.

BE

............... Let's come back to the aviation stuff.

11:02 am
BE

Welcome to Markets Live.

BE

Implications
Key risks to our 12- month price target of £10.4 (based on 2018E EV/NOPAT
of c.18x) include deterioration in maritime macro environment; excessive
cannibalisation of existing L-Band business from migration to GX; higher
capex; dividend cover in the mid-term.

BE

And Barclays ......

11:33 am
BE

ISAT posted Q3 results above expectations: group revenue is +2% above and group EBITDA is +8% above. Net income was below our expectation due to a one-off cost linked to a convertible issuance and early repurchase. The revenue beat was due to stronger than expected trends in government at +13% above consensus (+10% yoy vs +2% in Q2) thanks to GX related contract (take or pay) with primary channel partners. Maritime however was disappointing at -4% below consensus and declining -5% yoy (-0.5% in Q2) due to tough comparables but also continued decline of legacy products. The EBITDA beat is due to Government but also lower Central Service costs as a large part of the costs are in GBP (revenues in USD) and not hedged. Management indicated that the launch of the 4th GX satellite would be delayed to 2017 following the Space X failure and as such reduced 2016 capex guidance from USD500m-600m to USD400-500m. It did not increase however the capex guidance for 2017 or 2018 (USD500-600m).

BE

So, yes, this IAG short-haul contract.

BE

Putting "next-generation connectivity services" on 341 short-haul aircraft

11:35 am
BE

First aircraft to go live next summer.

BE

No information whatsoever on capex and opex.

BE

Not even any info on whether it's using the GX network. (Probably not, I'm told.)

11:37 am

We've talked before about the landgrab here, and the need to provide the boxes cheap on the hope of earning revenue around 2018 or 2019 ....

BE

BE

Here's Credit Suisse .....

11:38 am
BE

3 recent major commercial airline announcements further boost future
committed revenue. IAG (short-haul 341 aircraft), Air New Zealand and
another European airline have all recently confirmed they will be using
Inmarsat's GlobalXpress and/or European Aviation Network (EAN) for
passenger connectivity. Added to 3 recent major Maritime deals, the recent
US Navy contract win and 3 committed revenue deals in Government,
Aviation & Enterprise signed several years ago, we believe the airline
announcements further underpin Inmarsat's 3-5 year growth outlook.

BE

....... I remain to be convinced that commercial airline satcoms will ever be a serious earner. But what does that matter? Market's keen.

undefined
11:42 am
BE

This session's taking the form of a club sandwich .......

BE

......... Layer of Brexit ... layer of other stuff ... layer of Brexit .... layer of other stuff .......

BE

Plus the odd cocktail stick to skewer the roof of your mouth.

11:43 am
BE

Time for another Brexit layer. RBC supplies this one.

BE

The government will appeal this decision and it appears as though that appeal will take place in early December. As more than half the MPs in the House of Commons voted for Remain in the referendum there will be some doubt about whether such a vote will pass – presumably some of the positive reaction of GBP to the news reflects that doubt. However, given the government is adamant that “Brexit means Brexit”, the central case should remain that its slim majority ensures the vote is passed so that Article 50 can be triggered. In which case it may well be that GBP’s bounce is short-lived.

One potential consequence of this decision is that it may force the government to reveal more details about their plans for the nature and characteristics of the Brexit deal they are seeking in order to secure higher levels of support amongst MPs when it comes to the Article 50 vote in parliament. Many MPs may be willing to vote to trigger Article 50 if they feel they know what Brexit means. That could effectively bring forward the timeframe for meaningful news flow on the key economic aspects of the government’s preferred Brexit deal.

The appeals process notwithstanding, Article 50 is due to be triggered by March 2017. Therefore in the run up to that event there now seems more chance of a greater frequency of market-sensitive Brexit-related headlines and developments. This potential for volatility could well be an important factor for the MPC to take into account – at the margin the economic cost of increased uncertainty in the short-term should count as a factor in favour of a QE extension once the current programme comes to a close by February 2017.

undefined
11:46 am
BE

Regus is changing its name!

BE

And its domicile.

BE

It's becoming IWG of Switzerland.

11:47 am
BE

Not to be confused with IWC of Switzerland, the watch maker for traders who like brash wristweights but whose bonuses weren't quite as good as they were hoping.

Regus plc (RGU:LSE): Last: 245.60, up 3.9 (+1.61%), High: 249.50, Low: 240.90, Volume: 1.95m
BE

You'll note the shares have been on a terrible run since Mark Dixon slotted a load.

11:49 am
BE

And I think we noted at the time that Regus, as a hyper-cyclical, tends to react quite badly to any sign that its markets might be turning.

BE

Today's numbers suggest that they are indeed turning, though costs can damp the effect.

BE

RBC incoming.

11:50 am
BE

A mixed Q3 statement. Trading in the mature estate has weakened with growth of -2.6% vs -0.9% in Q2. However, this has been offset by continued strong
overhead performance resulting in strong profit (+30%) and cashflow (+52%) growth and improved ROI. Overall trading is in line with expectations. The group has
guided to overall capex of £150m albeit on a smaller number of openings. Fewer centres reflects more selectivity and some slippage into 2017, whilst the higher
costs reflects some freehold investment, forex and a potential bolt-on deal. We don’t expect to be changing profit forecasts, with the weaker growth offset by
forex and a better overhead performance.
The stock has been weak since H1s (U/P FTSE100 by 23%), on the back of macro concerns and the Mark Dixon share sale. Valuation is now undemanding
with the stock trading on a 17E PE of 13.5x. Whilst there are clearly some cyclical headwinds, Regus has an unrivaled market position, significant expansion
potential and strong structural growth drivers. We believe the existing estate is justified by the current share price and hence investors are getting growth potential for free. We would use recent weakness as a buying opportunity for the longer-term.

BE

In all of today's excitement I haven't asked why they're moving from Luxembourg to Switzerland.

BE

Tax rate's basically the same at 20%-ish.

11:52 am
BE

Is it simply that senior management live there already?

BE

Here's Investec.

BE

3Q16 reflects the group’s current state of transition. Operating profit growth in constant currency was at the 30% level seen at the interims, while underlying revenue growth slowed further to 3.8% (2Q16: 6.4%). ‘Mature’ revenues fell for the second successive quarter (-2.6%), which can be attributed to ‘softer’ conditions in some markets and higher closures YTD, reflecting management’s shift to a more selective, returns-focussed approach. With the outlook inline, our EPS forecasts are unchanged. Buy and 370p PT reiterated.

11:53 am
BE

FX tailwinds offset further slowdown in ‘mature’ revenues: 3Q16 group revenues rose 3.8% YoY in constant currency (headline: +18.4%); underlying growth slowing from 6.4% in 2Q16. ‘Mature’ (open more than 18 months) revenues (75% of group) fell 2.6% YoY in constant currency (vs 2Q16 -0.9% by our estimate). We attribute this to slowing growth in Asia, weaker macro in Latam and higher closures (mainly UK) driven in part by competition regulation.
Operating profit growth ‘in line’ on efficiency gains: despite mixed revenue development, constant currency operating profit growth was reportedly in line with 1H16’s 30%. This gives us confidence that ongoing efficiency gains and recent restructuring have further to run, offsetting any revenue slow-down.
More measured approach to capex: management signal a more selective rate of new openings with revised FY16 guidance of 240 new locations (previously 350). Conversely, guidance for FY16 net growth capex rises to £150m from £120m on the opportunistic acquisition of properties (£12.9m) and FX effect.

BE

(@roddy1234: dunno, plausibly?)

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,136, down 18 (-1.56%), High: 1,155, Low: 1,115, Volume: 1.84m
11:56 am
BE

Mixed bag.

BE

Shares sold off earlier in the week, rather illogically, to the Zimmer-Biomet warning.

BE

Which was caused entirely, it seems, by Zimmer's computers not working with Biomet's computers, meaning they had too few artificial knees in surgery storage rooms.

11:58 am
BE

Today we get news that S&N's ortho bit is indeed fine

BE

Hips flat, knees +4%

BE

Wouldcare still in trouble though. You'll remember the China destocking problem at the interims. Still not fixed.

11:59 am
BE

Guidance still for H2 to be better than H1.

BE

Jefferies to summarise.

BE

Conclusion: 3Q Sales came in a touch light at $1,119m (-1% vs cons 1,132m;
$1,109-1,153m). Underlying growth of 2% was below cons (3%), driven by softness in
Wound (-1% underlying) but China has returned to growth on a Group basis (Trauma +ve
as flagged; Wound should turn +ve in 1Q17). Recon held up well as flagged (+4% in knees)
underlining our view that -ve read-x from ZBH was misplaced. Guidance affirmed (expect
2H margin greater than 1H). To deliver FY16 guidance of SN/ must generate a margin of greater than 24.3% in 2H
which is challenging but feasible if resilience in non-Wound segments continues into 4Q.
We expect Wound to recover from 1Q17 as China returns to +ve growth. SN/ trades at 14.2x FY17 P/E (-22% vs Stryker 18.0x; -28% vs Sector 19.8x), despite each offering in-line EPS growth (11-12% FY16-19).

12:01 pm
BE

And Cantor.

BE

Management has worked assiduously to diversify Smith & Nephew’s business making the company less reliant on its ortho recon past. However, the previous focus on the younger more active patient brought higher margin revenues which delivered operating leverage more easily. In response, efforts to streamline the business haven’t been enough to deliver trading margin aspirations to date. Recently, it has been the impact of the emerging markets exposure (China) as well as the Gulf States and Fx, leading to forecast downgrades. Nevertheless, the Sports Medicine business continues to strengthen and we welcome growth in ortho recon in particular. We maintain our HOLD recommendation.
